abstract.t: A Thing-to-Thing Data Hub is a RESTful, hypermedia-driven Web application that can be used in Thing-to-Thing communication toshare information such as thing descriptions, configurations, resource descriptions or firmware updates at a central location.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: In Thing-to-Thing communication, there is often a need to share information of common interest at a central location. For example, a CoRE Resource Directory aggregates descriptions of resources held on other servers, which enables things to easily discover these resources. Similarly, a W3C Web-of-Things Thing Description Repository stores the semantic metadata of things as well as functional descriptions of their interfaces, making this information available to Web dashboards, commissioning tools and other things.

As more and more thing-to-thing applications are implemented, it becomes increasingly important to be able to share also other data than resource and thing descriptions, such as the sleep schedules of devices, default configurations for new devices, firmware updates, or certificate revocation lists. Resource directory and thing description repository are not always the best fit for this kind of data and defining a new specialized application for each use case is not practical in the long term.

This document defines a simple "data hub" application, a RESTful Web application suitable for constrained environments that generalizes the concept of a central entity for sharing information. A data hub enables clients to share data items in any media type and provides means for creating, reading, observing, updating, deleting and finding shared items at a data hub server.

The application is presented in the style of a CoRE Application Description. That is, the focus of the application interface is on the media types used by the data hub and all interactions are driven by links and forms.

Features:
General
The generalization to any media type provides two advantages. The first is media type agility: applications using the data hub won't be stuck forever with the same media types. The second, as mentioned above, is that it may be useful to share also other information than resource and thing descriptions.
Searchable
Submitting a search query allows clients to retrieve a subset of items from a data hub. Without this feature, a client would have to download and sort through the whole set of shared items. It is more efficient to filter the set at the data hub server. To make this work with any media type, a search request needs to specify both the media type of the desired items and a media type-specific search query.
Observable
The items published to a data hub are exposed as resources and as such can be observed for changes. This allows clients to stay informed of information that other clients update over a period of time. In effect, the data hub is similar in functioning to a CoAP Publish-Subscribe Broker, although this isn't the primary use case of a data hub.
Evolvable
The key differentiator of the data hub compared to resource directory and publish-subscribe broker lies in the evolvability -- the ability to respond effectively to change (such as the addition of new features) without negatively impacting both existing and new clients. The definition of the application interfaces purely in terms of standardized URI templates makes it very difficult to gradually evolve them; there are no versioning or capability negotiation mechanisms. The data hub facilitates fine-grained evolvability by driving all interactions by machine-understandable hypertext. Features can be added, changed or removed in a safe, backwards-compatible way simply by updating the data hub representation to expose matching links and forms.

section.title: Data Model
section.t: The data model consists of four parts. The central part is the data hub, which has a number of shared items (). A data hub can be queried with a search query, which yields a search result.

figure.title: A Data Hub with a Number of Shared Items

list.t: A data hub resource is a collection of shared data items. Its representation primarily consists of links to the data item resources using the "item" link relation type. To reduce the number of round-trips, it MAY also embed (complete or partial) representations of those item resources. Forms contained in the data hub representation enable interactions with the hub and items, as described in the following section. Additional links and forms not described here MAY be present (for example, a link with the "alternate" link relation type that references an alternate representation of the data hub resource).

For a start, a data hub has only a depth of one level; i.e., all data item resources are organized directly under the top-level data hub resource. This could be extended to multiple levels in a future revision of this draft.
Data hub representations are formatted in the "application/coral" media type.
A data hub item is a member of the collection.
Item representations can in principle be formatted in any media type; a data hub deployment MAY restrict the media types it accepts for publication, though.
The representations of items MAY link back to a data hub resource using the "collection" link relation type.

section.title: Interaction Model
section.t: The interaction model consists of eight possible interactions with a data hub: discovering and reading the data hub, and creating, reading, observing, updating, deleting and finding shared items in the data hub.

list.t: For a start, nodes are assumed to be pre-configured out-of-band with a link to a data hub.

A node can retrieve a representation of the data hub by following the discovered link. The representation of the data hub includes links to (and/or literals with representations of) the items in the data hub. The data hub representation MAY also include forms for creating, updating, deleting and finding items.

The representation of a data hub MAY contain a form with the "create-item" form relation type. Submitting this form with a representation in one of the accepted content formats creates a new item in the data hub.
A node can retrieve a representation of an item by following one of the links with the "item" link relation type in the data hub representation.
A node can observe an item by following one of the links with the "item" link relation type in the data hub representation and observing the target resource as specified in .

For each item in a data hub, the representation of the data hub MAY indicate that the item is updatable. If an item is updatable, the link to the item includes the CoRAL Updatable Option, which defines a form with the "update" form relation type. Submitting this form updates the item in the data hub to the submitted representation.

For each item in a data hub, the representation of the data hub MAY indicate that the item is deletable. If an item is deletable, the link to the item includes the CoRAL Deletable Option, which defines a form with the "delete" form relation type. Submitting this form deletes the item from the data hub.

The representation of a data hub MAY contain a form with the "search" form relation type, which can be used to find items in the data hub. Submitting this form with a media type and a media type-specific filter query returns a subset of the data hub that matches the filter. (The details of this are TODO.)

section.title: Related Work
section.t: The data hub is an instance of the well-known collection pattern. As such, it might be used in places where a more specialized instance of the collection pattern is currently used, such as the bulletin board of CoRE Lighting, the CoAP Publish-Subscribe Broker, or the CoRE Resource Directory. This section shows how these might be implemented using a data hub (without trying to replicate all of their features in detail).

section.title: CoRE Lighting
section.t: CoRE Lighting uses a JSON-based "bulletin board" to discover things such as light bulbs and light switches. Things are described by a thing description that contains both human-readable information and machine-understandable hypermedia controls which indicate the possible interactions with the thing.

figure.title: A Data Hub Storing Thing Descriptions

section.t: shows a data hub with two thing descriptions, matching the example in Section 5.2.1 of . The first thing description describes a light bulb and has a link with the "config" link relation type pointing to the configuration of the light bulb. The second thing description describes a light remote control (LRC) and has a link with the "about" link relation type pointing to the observable state of the LRC.
Thing descriptions are represented in the "application/thing-description+json" media type (content format 65200 in the example). A data hub representation thus could look as shown in .

section.title: CoAP Publish-Subscribe
section.t: CoAP Publish-Subscribe provides means for sensor and actuator nodes with limited reachability to publish and receive data without having to be reachable at the same time. The basic operation involves clients called "publishers" updating "topic" resources at a server called the "broker", and clients called "subscribers" observing these resources ().

A broker might be implemented as a data hub by creating the topics as resources on the data hub server and linking to these from the data hub resource with the "item" link relation type (). Hypermedia controls in the data hub representation enable publishers to create, update and delete topics, and subscribers to read/observe these topics.

section.title: CoRE Resource Directory
section.t: A CoRE Resource Directory hosts descriptions of resources held on other servers, allowing lookups to be performed for those descriptions. The descriptions are encoded as links in CoRE Link Format that are annotated with a variety of link attributes providing the type of and hints about the linked resources.
A data hub might store these resource descriptions such that each resource description becomes one item in the data hub and each item links to the respective resource ().

section.title: CoRE Mirror Server
section.t: Similar to a CoAP Publish-Subscribe Broker, a CoRE Mirror Server allows a sleepy device to store representations of their resources so that other devices can access the representations while it is sleeping.
